instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.SLP_S5_L: What is SLP_S5_L? SLP_S5_L is an abbreviation for PM_SLP_S5_L.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Missing S4
threads.message:
Happy Thanksgiving!

I bought an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that was liquid damaged. It [I]sometimes[/I] turns on after leaving it alone for a while (albeit doesn't boot, but that might be a separate problem).

Right now, these are what I probed for (not in order). It shows 0.05A and 20V from the USB-C meter. I poured Alcohol on the board and it doesn't get [I]that[/I] hot anywhere.
[LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.62V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.327V
[*]<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 0V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.15V
[*]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL> - 12.62V
[*]<SIGNAL>P5VS0_TG</SIGNAL> - 0V
[*]<SIGNAL>P5VS0_VBST_R</SIGNAL> - 4.79V
[*]<SIGNAL>P5VS4_SW</SIGNAL> - 0V
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVXS5</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
[*][B]<SIGNAL>P5VS5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0V[/B]
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
[*]<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0V 100Ohm to ground right after powering off but rises to 90k
[*][B]<SIGNAL>P5VS4_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0V[/B]
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
[*]<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_SW</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVXS5</SIGNAL> - 3.42V[/B]
[*][B]<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_RCD</SIGNAL> - 3.3V[/B]
[*][B]<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_COMP2</SIGNAL> - 1.96V[/B]
[/LIST]

I think the main problem is that <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing even though <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_RCD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVXS5</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL> is present. Does this mean I have to change <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>? I don't see any damage near there. I don't have an ultrasonic cleaner so would prefer to root-cause it before purchasing one.

Thank you!
Rohit

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Missing S4
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R7802</RESISTOR> resistor; may need to replace it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Missing S4
threads.message:
So somehow I now have <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> but I don't have <SIGNAL>P5VS4_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, and <RESISTOR>R7802</RESISTOR> is approximately 100K.

I then found that <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN_RCD</SIGNAL> is missing , and more importantly that <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> (its dependency) is missing.

Could you please point me what PCH signals need to be present for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> to be alive? I see some articles online but they're for older gen CPUs. This is a 7th gen Intel - I have no idea how <SIGNAL>SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is released.

[U]Sanity check:[/U]
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.00V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0.00V

[U]Pins around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>:[/U]
- <SIGNAL>P5VS4_DRVL</SIGNAL> (DRVL1 pin) - 0V
- <SIGNAL>P5VS4_DRVH</SIGNAL> (DRVH1 pin) - 0V
- <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> (PGOOD2 pin) - 3.28V
- <SIGNAL>P5VS4_PGOOD</SIGNAL> (PGOOD1 pin) - 0V
- <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN_RCD</SIGNAL> (EN1 pin) - 0V
- <SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVXS5</SIGNAL> (EN pin) - 3.417V
- <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> (VREG3 pin) - 3.3V
- <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL> (VREF2 pin) - 2.00V

[U]Figuring out why <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN_RCD</SIGNAL> is dead:[/U]
- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
- <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.417V

[U]Going through some related PCH voltages:[/U]
- <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> (checked for stability) - 3.08V
- <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.078V
- <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.07V
- <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> (I think this won't come until S0?) - 0V
- <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 3.31V
- <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
- <SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
[B]- <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 2.78V (Seems lower?)[/B]

Thanks again, I appreciate the help.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Missing S4
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> signals.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
Use SW5200, or <RESISTOR>R5226</RESISTOR> pads, instead of power button.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Missing S4
threads.message:
- <SIGNAL>PM_RMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
- <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32V

When I short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground at SW5200, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (measured at <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR>) goes to a few millivolts while I hold the short. It then comes back to 3.3V when I release the short.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Missing S4
threads.message:
Then check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time.
Do the same for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL>.
